Stem: Several green hairy erect flowering stems per plant.
Leaves: Egg shaped hairy up to 30 cm long in rosette at base, stem leaves smaller and narrower, also hairy.
Flowers: Usually purple, but also blue or white. 2-3 cm long. Trumpet shaped with 5 stamens, 2 of which protrude out of flower.
FruitSeeds: Dark brown or grey with roughened coat. Up to 4 per flower.
Habitat: Wide habitat tolerance, can grow almost anywhere in Australia. Prefers winter-rainfall areas. Roadsides and agricultural areas.
DistinguishingFeatures: Distinguished from Vipers bugloss (*Echium vulgare*) by fewer stamens protruding outside flower.
Impacts: Outcompetes and replaces crops, pasture or native vegetation. Can be toxic to stock in high doses.
